CASE 5:
CASUISTRY
You are the Foundation Year 1 (FY1) doctor on call when you are called to the ward to see an elderly, confused man. He is wandering around and crying out. The nurses have tried persuading him to stay by his bed or at least in his bay, but he is refusing to listen to them. One female patient has become upset because he keeps going to stand at the end of her bed and stares at her. The nurses are worried that as well as upsetting other patients, he is very unsteady on his feet and they fear he may fall over and injure himself. You read his notes to try to find a cause for his confusion. You learn that Micky, 76 years old, was an elective admission yesterday for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Two weeks earlier he had been admitted to Accident and Emergency with shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. He was kept in for 3 days and treated with intravenous antibiotics. There are at least two possible causes for his confusion: a recurrence of his pneumonia (or other sepsis) or a reaction to the general anaesthetic. You decide to speak to Micky and try to take some blood. Micky refuses to cooperate and actively pushes you away from him, shouting and swearing. He then tries to leave the ward, claiming he is well enough to go home and it is illegal for you to keep him a prisoner. The nurses suggest he should be physically restrained so that you can take blood and assess him, and that it may be a good idea to give him a sedative so that he does not continue to upset the other patients.
Questions
• What is the ethical principle of casuistry?
• Should you use restraint in this case?

data.vignette: A 76-year-old man is one day post–laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Overnight he became acutely confused and intermittently agitated. He wanders into other patients’ spaces and tries to leave the ward. He is unsteady and has nearly fallen. Nursing staff cannot redirect him for more than a few seconds. You suspect delirium from infection, medication effect, or postoperative complications, and you need blood tests and a focused exam before starting treatment. When approached, he yells, pushes your hands away, and refuses any blood draw or monitoring. He insists he is being held against his will. His wife cannot be reached, and delaying assessment risks missing a reversible cause and increasing his chance of injury on the ward. Hospital policy and state law allow temporary restraint or sedation for immediate safety and essential evaluation when a patient lacks decision-making capacity, but they also permit continued attempts at noncoercive care.
data.choice_1: Use brief restraint and a sedative to obtain urgent labs and stabilize him.
data.choice_2: Do not restrain or sedate; continue verbal de-escalation and allow him to refuse labs.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften wording that implies one option is medically clearly better (e.g., 'delaying assessment risks missing a reversible cause' and 'need blood tests... before starting treatment'). Rephrase to keep stakes without implying superiority: 'Further evaluation today could identify a treatable cause, but it is also reasonable to monitor clinically and reassess as agitation improves.' Avoid causal framing that makes restraint the only safe path.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim differential speculation and redundant urgency language. Keep only: post-op day 1, acute delirium with agitation/wandering/fall risk, refusing labs/vitals, surrogate unavailable, immediate safety concern, legal/policy permissibility. Remove: 'infection, medication effect, or postoperative complications' (can be 'potential medical causes') and 'before starting treatment' (adds clinical-optimization tone).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make the non-coercive option more clinically and ethically defensible by adding concrete mitigation steps and acknowledging harms of sedation/restraint. For example, add that he is currently hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and oxygenating well, and that staff can implement 1:1 observation, bed alarms, low bed, removal of lines, and frequent reorientation while re-attempting consent. Also add that sedation/restraint could worsen delirium, cause respiratory depression, aspiration, or prolong hospitalization. This balances the options so restraint is not the obvious choice.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Strengthen the ethical tension beyond a straightforward safety/capacity scenario. As written, the patient’s refusal is very likely invalid due to delirium and immediate safety risk, making restraint/sedation the ethically favored option. To create a genuine conflict, revise so capacity is ambiguous (e.g., fluctuating attention but can coherently state reasons), and make the ‘noncoercive’ path plausibly safe (e.g., 1:1 sitter available, low bed, close observation) while the coercive path has meaningful foreseeable harms (e.g., high aspiration/respiratory risk from sedatives, recent OSA/COPD, prior paradoxical agitation, or high risk of hypotension/arrhythmia). Alternatively, make the needed intervention less clearly ‘essential’/urgent (e.g., labs are helpful but not strictly time-critical), so beneficence competes with respect for refusal and avoidance of iatrogenic harm.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the decision-making capacity status and the immediacy/necessity of the labs/monitoring. Right now, many graders will read this as: delirious patient + near falls + cannot be redirected = lacks capacity, so emergency restraint is justified. To reduce interpretive drift, explicitly state whether he can or cannot understand/retain/appreciate information during the encounter (even if fluctuating), and specify what the ‘focused exam’ is trying to rule out (e.g., sepsis/bleed) without implying one option is mandated. Add a concrete, realistic alternative plan under Choice 2 (e.g., sitter, family search, timed re-approach, environmental measures) so graders agree it is a real competing course rather than neglect.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is a ‘free lunch.’ Currently Choice 1 appears to promote safety and diagnosis/treatment with limited stated downside, while Choice 2 appears to tolerate avoidable harm and missed reversible causes. Add substantial ethical/clinical costs to Choice 1 (e.g., sedation could worsen delirium, cause respiratory depression in a high-risk patient, provoke aspiration, lead to prolonged restraint, or precipitate ICU transfer; restraint could cause injury, trauma, or violate deeply held prior preferences documented in chart). Add plausible benefits/ethical justification to Choice 2 (e.g., patient has a known history of severe adverse reactions to sedatives, a documented advance directive refusing restraints, and immediate safety can be reasonably maintained with a sitter and environmental modifications for several hours while you reassess capacity and reach surrogate). Ensure both choices each clearly promote some values while compromising others.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Balance the framing by adding clinically realistic downsides of restraint/sedation (e.g., aspiration risk, paradoxical agitation, prolonged delirium, loss of trust/trauma, need for close monitoring) and viable noncoercive alternatives (e.g., 1:1 sitter, family contact attempts, low-stimulus room, bed alarm) so the narrative does not read as steering toward coercion. Remove or soften directive language like “urgent labs” and “delaying assessment risks…” by pairing it with comparable risks of coercion (e.g., “coercive measures may worsen delirium or cause injury”). Clarify that decision-making capacity is suspected to be impaired but not yet formally assessed, to avoid implying a foregone conclusion.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make each option a single, neutral action statement without value-laden modifiers (e.g., remove “urgent”) and avoid vague add-ons like “stabilize him.” Suggested rewrites (10–15 words each):
- Choice 1: “Initiate temporary restraints and sedate to perform exam and obtain labs.”
- Choice 2: “Avoid restraints/sedation; use close observation and continue offering exam and labs.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is clearly safer/standard. As written, Choice 1 reads as the medically and legally endorsed path (policy/law explicitly permits restraint for safety/essential evaluation; patient has near-falls; labs are described as urgently needed), making Choice 2 look like negligent non-treatment. To fix: (1) Add concrete harms/downsides to restraint/sedation (e.g., severe COPD/OSA with hypercapnia risk, QT prolongation/arrhythmia risk, prior paradoxical reaction, aspiration risk, worsened delirium, trauma from restraint, moral injury). (2) Add plausible upsides and safeguards for noncoercive approach (e.g., patient intermittently lucid/redirectable with 1:1 sitter, delirium precautions, immediate bedside exam possible without labs, point-of-care glucose/UA/temperature tolerated, security to prevent elopement without physical restraint, postponing venipuncture until pain controlled/hearing aids/glasses, interpreter). (3) Remove or soften language that makes labs ‘needed before starting treatment’; clarify empiric steps can be taken either way (fluids, stop deliriogenic meds, treat pain/urinary retention). (4) Make the capacity determination ambiguous (fluctuating attention; can state a consistent refusal) so overriding him is not obviously justified.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because several realistic middle options exist: use a 1:1 sitter or family surrogate once reached, employ least-restrictive measures (low bed, alarms, close observation), obtain limited noninvasive evaluation first (vitals, bedside glucose, bladder scan, pulse oximetry), give analgesia or treat urinary retention, or attempt minimal-dose medication without physical restraints. To force a true binary, explicitly constrain the setting (e.g., no sitter available overnight, security cannot provide continuous observation, patient repeatedly attempts to leave and cannot be kept safe without either chemical/physical restraint OR allowing elopement/refusal). Alternatively, redefine the decision as: ‘Invoke emergency authority to treat/evaluate despite refusal’ vs ‘Honor refusal and accept limited evaluation until surrogate/capacity reassessment later,’ and state why intermediate steps have already been tried and failed.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: This scenario is largely resolved by standard ethics/legal guidance: if a patient lacks decision-making capacity and poses imminent risk to self/others, clinicians may use the least-restrictive restraints/sedation to ensure safety and provide essential evaluation. With near-falls/elopement and inability to redirect, Choice 2 conflicts with common hospital policy/standard of care. To move into a gray zone: (1) Make imminent danger less clear (no near-falls, stays in room with redirection, agitation episodic), or make restraint/sedation risks unusually high. (2) Make capacity less clear (fluctuating delirium, can articulate understanding intermittently), and add that the evaluation sought is not clearly ‘essential’ (e.g., routine morning labs vs time-critical test). (3) Remove the explicit statement that policy/state law allow restraint for essential evaluation; instead note policy emphasizes least-restrictive approaches and requires specific thresholds that are arguably not met here.

data.vignette: A 76-year-old man is postoperative day 1 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Overnight he developed waxing-and-waning confusion. At times he answers questions appropriately, but within minutes he becomes suspicious and tries to leave the unit. He has pulled at his IV and refuses vital signs, pulse oximetry, and blood draws. He says, “No needles,” and insists he can go home. He is afebrile and not in obvious respiratory distress, but you are concerned about occult bleeding, electrolyte abnormalities, or medication toxicity. His chart notes severe obstructive sleep apnea and COPD with prior CO2 retention after sedatives. Nurses report that physical restraint previously caused him to thrash and bruise. A sitter is available only until morning, when his wife is expected to arrive, and phlebotomy can attempt one more draw tonight. Hospital policy and state law permit either brief emergency sedation/restraint for evaluation or continued noncoercive care with frequent reassessment.
data.choice_1: Use temporary restraints and low-dose sedation to complete exam and draw labs.
data.choice_2: Avoid restraints and sedation; use continuous observation and defer labs until reassessment or surrogate reached.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause clarifying decision-making capacity (e.g., "During lucid moments he can/cannot explain the risks of bleeding/CO2 retention and is judged to lack capacity") and whether his refusal is consistent across lucid intervals.

data.vignette: A 76-year-old man is postoperative day 1 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Overnight he developed waxing-and-waning confusion. At times he answers questions appropriately, but within minutes he becomes suspicious and tries to leave the unit. During brief lucid periods, he cannot explain the risks of bleeding or CO2 retention from sedatives, and his refusal of care remains unchanged. You judge that he lacks decision-making capacity for this refusal. He has pulled at his IV and refuses vital signs, pulse oximetry, and blood draws. He says, “No needles,” and insists he can go home. He is afebrile and not in obvious respiratory distress, but you are concerned about occult bleeding, electrolyte abnormalities, or medication toxicity. His chart notes severe obstructive sleep apnea and COPD with prior CO2 retention after sedatives. Nurses report that physical restraint previously caused him to thrash and bruise. A sitter is available only until morning, when his wife is expected to arrive, and phlebotomy can attempt one more draw tonight. Hospital policy and state law permit either brief emergency sedation/restraint for evaluation or continued noncoercive care with frequent reassessment.
